title: The Tomb of the Cybermen
dialogue_triumphs: The Doctor reassures Victoria, missing her father, with recollections of his own family: 'I have to really want to, to bring them back in front of my eyes. The rest of the time they… sleep in my mind and I forget. And so will you.'
dialogue_disasters: 'You scream real good, Vic,' the captain tells Victoria, who mutters, 'Who'd be a woman?' 'How would you know, honey?' he replies.
goofs: In episode one the Doctor and Jamie hold one of the tomb doors closed with their feet.
The Cybercontroller uses a visible harness to lift Toberman over his head.
Toberman returns the favour by spinning a dummy Cybercontroller.
The Cybermen retreat into their tombs backwards, the film having been reversed.

continuity_notes.name: TARDIS
continuity_notes.description: The Doctor's time machine and spacecraft
continuity_notes.current_status: Appears to land like a spaceship in this episode

continuity_notes.name: The Doctor
continuity_notes.description: The main protagonist, a Time Lord from Gallifrey

continuity_notes.name: Cybermats
continuity_notes.description: Small, cybernetic creatures associated with the Cybermen
continuity_notes.current_status: Two sizes exist; the Doctor has a picture of one in his book but is unfamiliar with them

continuity_notes.name: Cybermen
continuity_notes.current_status: Sealed in their tombs for 500 years; bullet-proof, can fire sparks from fingers, and control cybernised humans remotely

technobabble: The X-ray laser is the Cybermen's standard weapon
The weapon testing room features a psychedelic target that can hypnotise humans, with a 'subliminal centre you're trained to see'
roots: Mummy movies, especially Hammer's The Mummy (starring George Pastell) and The Curse of the Mummy's Tomb
The Avengers episode 'The House that Jack Built'

locations.name: Telos
locations.description: Planet where the Cybermen have been entombed
locations.current_status: Has a rarefied atmosphere; site of Cybermen tombs

future_history: The Brotherhood of Logicians are a collective of the time's great thinkers, believing that logic and intelligence are supreme virtues. Orbiters send rockets down to planets. Parry's expedition is privately financed.
additional_notes: Victoria seems only slightly concerned by switching from Victorian gown to mini-dress. It's one of the few stories to feature anoraks.
bottom_line: The first two episodes are wonderful, a well-directed and expensive-looking restating of the series' basics, but once the Cybermen are released from the Tombs, they go back in again.
